You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of condition:
```c
static int condition(void)
{
	int ret;
	int ts_created;
	pthread_t tids[THREADS];

	/** TC1 consumer threads go first */
	/** create 10 consumer threads first */
	ret = metal_run_noblock(THREADS, consumer_thread, NULL, tids,
				&ts_created);
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to create consumer thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
		goto out;
	}

	/** create 10 producer threads next */
	ret = metal_run(THREADS, producer_thread, NULL);
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to create producer thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
		goto out;
	}

	/** wait for consumer threads to finish */
	metal_finish_threads(THREADS, (void *)tids);

	/** TC2 producer threads go first */
	/** create 10 producer threads first */
	ret = metal_run_noblock(THREADS, producer_thread, NULL, tids,
				&ts_created);
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to create consumer thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
		goto out;
	}

	/** create 10 consumer threads next */
	ret = metal_run(THREADS, consumer_thread, NULL);
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to create producer thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
		goto out;
	}

out:
	/** wait for producer threads to finish */
	metal_finish_threads(THREADS, (void *)tids);
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler-specific language extensions are present in the provided code fragment. I inspected for common compiler extensions that are explicitly documented as such (for example: identifiers or keywords beginning with __, GCC/Clang attributes (__attribute__), typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, nested functions, inline assembly (asm), label-as-values, Microsoft-specific keywords, or other non-standard syntax). None are used.

Specific notes explaining why other constructs do NOT require investigation with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2:
- Declarations (int ret; int ts_created; pthread_t tids[THREADS];) use standard C syntax. If THREADS is not a compile-time constant and thus yields a VLA, VLAs are a standard C feature (C99); they are not a compiler extension per se. (If your toolchain treats VLAs as an extension, that would be a toolchain-specific policy but is not visible in this fragment.)
- pthread_t and pthread-related functions are POSIX threading API usages, not language/compiler extensions.
- Calls to metal_run_noblock, metal_run, metal_finish_threads, and metal_log are calls to library functions; library usage is not a language extension.
- The cast (void *)tids is standard C pointer casting/decay behavior; it is not a compiler extension.
- Use of goto/out label, comments (/* ... */ and /** ... */), return, and control-flow constructs are all standard C.

Because no explicit compiler extension tokens or constructs appear in the snippet, there are no fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
